body:
This code works for me:
(added parameters that make the initial window longer and sub-sample)

```python
from sktime.datasets import load_airline
from sktime.forecasting.arima import AutoARIMA, ARIMA
from sktime.forecasting.conformal import ConformalIntervals

y = load_airline()
trial_forecaster = AutoARIMA()
conformal_forecaster = ConformalIntervals(trial_forecaster, method="conformal", initial_window=12, sample_frac=0.1)
conformal_forecaster.fit(y, fh=[1,2,3])
```

so it might have to do sth with too short initial window.

It that's all there is (unsure), an informative error message should be returned.

rename.to: [BUG] ConformalIntervals wrapped ARIMA/AutoARIMA breaks with default parameters

body:
Have looked into this and it appears to just be too short `initial_window` since auto-arima does some slicing of the data and it  requires more than one data point. The exact number of data points it requires is [defined by r from sarimax](https://github.com/statsmodels/statsmodels/blob/2eac8066b068a88f00a29f8ff728b04e58248375/statsmodels/tsa/statespace/sarimax.py#L820), i.e. it will be `r+1`:

```
    def _conditional_sum_squares(endog, k_ar, polynomial_ar, k_ma,
                                 polynomial_ma, k_trend=0, trend_data=None,
                                 warning_description=None):
        k = 2 * k_ma
        r = max(k + k_ma, k_ar)
    
        ....
    
        Y = endog[r:]
```

I'm not sure if there is an easy way to pre-calculate this for the model. Thoughts @fkiraly?

Possible solutions I can think of:
* making the default initial window of `ConformalInterval` longer. That does not cover all possible cases (since `r` can be arbitrarily high), but perhaps most cases appearing in actual use
* adding a note or caveat at somewhere in the algorithm description, and/or next to the `initial_window` parameter

?

A more sophisticated solution would be to attach, to each algorithm, a "minimal training set size" parameter, which propagates through composites - although that would be a lot of work since it can depend on hyper-parameters. It would also complicate both the design and the developer contract.

@fkiraly  Yes. One option is we don't pass `initial_window` at all and we take (say) 5% of the data points as the initial window, as long as it is >= some value. Another option is just adding to the `initial_window` docstring, but I would assume an  `initial_window` of just 1 will always be a poor model and maybe over-estimate the overall interval? I think I need to test this and also check the literature.

Hmm, I see - your suggestion is to allow `float` for `initial_window`, interpreting this as a fraction, and then leave a fraction as the default?

Makes sense!

Another thing I noticed when I was thinking about the impacts of runtime, `sample_frac` might also be confusing for a user to control, since it is a fraction of a total that the user will not have a grasp of, rather than a parameter that links to absolute runtime. Would a parameter `n_samples` or similar be better to control the runtime here?

Yes thats right on `initial_window` although may run in to problems if that dataframe passed to the function is small (i.e. we pass 0.05 as `initial_window` fraction and the data only has 10 items say...), so could do something like `max(initial_window*len(y), 1)`, but that wouldn't solve the priblem above if `len(y)` is too small.

On the second point, happy to update it to `n_samples` and I guess default to `n_samples=len(y_index)`

> On the second point, happy to update it to n_samples and I guess default to n_samples=len(y_index)

Perhaps - I would not remove arguments, but we can make it like in `train_test_split` that accepts multiple types (integers, floats, etc) which are interpreted differently.

We also need to be cautious about deprecations, i.e., all calls to the estimator need to behave the same until version 0.15.0, possibly raising deprecation messages if we want to change the behaviour. But, optimally, we can figure something out so we do not even need to deprecate? Would have to sit down and think about this carefully, but probably you already have a good idea what/how to change?
This might be another instance of "too small training set": https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/3194

issue.title: [BUG] ARIMA and AutoARIMA not working within ConformalIntervals

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body: When I try to generate predict intervals with ConformalIntervals it gives an error. You would say I'd directly use the predict_interavals method, but in my case the idea is to obtain the intervals from a Time Series Ensemble model. And when I pass that ensemble to the ConformalIntervals, and the enemble contains ARIMA or AutoArima model, it fails. Any idea to get prediction intervals for an ensemble model? Error: --------------------------------------------------------------------------- IndexError Traceback (most recent call last) Input In [25], in () 5 forecaster = ARIMA() 6 conformal_forecaster = ConformalIntervals(forecaster) ----> 7 conformal_forecaster.fit(y, fh=[1,2,3]) 8 pred_int = conformal_forecaster.predict_interval() File ~\.conda\envs\sktime_arima\lib\site-packages\sktime\forecasting\base\_base.py:270, in BaseForecaster.fit(self, y, X, fh) 268 # we call the ordinary _fit if no looping/vectorization needed 269 if not vectorization_needed: --> 270 self._fit(y=y_inner, X=X_inner, fh=fh) 271 else: 272 # otherwise we call the vectorized version of fit 273 self._vectorize("fit", y=y_inner, X=X_inner, fh=fh) File ~\.conda\envs\sktime_arima\lib\site-packages\sktime\forecasting\conformal.py:140, in ConformalIntervals._fit(self, y, X, fh) 137 self.forecaster_.fit(y=y, X=X, fh=fh) 139 if self.fh_early_: --> 140 self.residuals_matrix_ = self._compute_sliding_residuals( 141 y=y, 142 X=X, 143 forecaster=self.forecaster, 144 initial_window=self.initial_window, 145 sample_frac=self.sample_frac, 146 ) 148 return self File ~\.conda\envs\sktime_arima\lib\site-packages\sktime\forecasting\conformal.py:290, in ConformalIntervals._compute_sliding_residuals(self, y, X, forecaster, initial_window, sample_frac) 287 X_test = get_slice(X, start=id, end=None) 289 try: --> 290 forecaster.fit(y_train, X=X_train, fh=y_test.index) 291 except ValueError: 292 warn( 293 f"Couldn't fit the model on " 294 f"time series window length {len(y_train)}.\n" 295 ) File ~\.conda\envs\sktime_arima\lib\site-packages\sktime\forecasting\base\_base.py:270, in BaseForecaster.fit(self, y, X, fh) 268 # we call the ordinary _fit if no looping/vectorization needed 269 if not vectorization_needed: --> 270 self._fit(y=y_inner, X=X_inner, fh=fh) 271 else: 272 # otherwise we call the vectorized version of fit 273 self._vectorize("fit", y=y_inner, X=X_inner, fh=fh) File ~\.conda\envs\sktime_arima\lib\site-packages\sktime\forecasting\base\adapters\_pmdarima.py:52, in _PmdArimaAdapter._fit(self, y, X, fh) 50 X = X.loc[y.index] 51 self._forecaster = self._instantiate_model() ---> 52 self._forecaster.fit(y, X=X) 53 return self File ~\.conda\envs\sktime_arima\lib\site-packages\pmdarima\arima\arima.py:597, in ARIMA.fit(self, y, X, **fit_args) 594 X = safe_indexing(X, slice(0, n_exog - cv)) 596 # Internal call --> 597 self._fit(y, X, **fit_args) 599 # now make a forecast if we're validating to compute the 600 # out-of-sample score 601 if cv_samples is not None: 602 # get the predictions (use self.predict, which calls forecast 603 # from statsmodels internally) File ~\.conda\envs\sktime_arima\lib\site-packages\pmdarima\arima\arima.py:520, in ARIMA._fit(self, y, X, **fit_args) 518 fit, self.arima_res_ = _fit_wrapper() 519 else: --> 520 fit, self.arima_res_ = _fit_wrapper() 522 # Set df_model attribute for SARIMAXResults object 523 sm_compat.bind_df_model(fit, self.arima_res_) File ~\.conda\envs\sktime_arima\lib\site-packages\pmdarima\arima\arima.py:508, in ARIMA._fit.._fit_wrapper() 504 # kwargs that might be in fit args, but if not we override the 505 # defaults 506 disp = fit_args.pop("disp", 0) --> 508 return arima, arima.fit(start_params=start_params, 509 method=method, 510 maxiter=_maxiter, 511 disp=disp, 512 **fit_args) File ~\.conda\envs\sktime_arima\lib\site-packages\statsmodels\tsa\statespace\mlemodel.py:650, in MLEModel.fit(self, start_params, transformed, includes_fixed, cov_type, cov_kwds, method, maxiter, full_output, disp, callback, return_params, optim_score, optim_complex_step, optim_hessian, flags, low_memory, **kwargs) 530 """ 531 Fits the model by maximum likelihood via Kalman filter. 532 (...) 647 statsmodels.tsa.statespace.structural.UnobservedComponentsResults 648 """ 649 if start_params is None: --> 650 start_params = self.start_params 651 transformed = True 652 includes_fixed = True File ~\.conda\envs\sktime_arima\lib\site-packages\statsmodels\tsa\statespace\sarimax.py:953, in SARIMAX.start_params(self) 949 params_exog = [] 951 # Non-seasonal ARMA component and trend 952 (params_trend, params_ar, params_ma, --> 953 params_variance) = self._conditional_sum_squares( 954 endog, self.k_ar, self.polynomial_ar, self.k_ma, 955 self.polynomial_ma, self._k_trend, trend_data, 956 warning_description='ARMA and trend') 958 # If we have estimated non-stationary start parameters but enforce 959 # stationarity is on, start with 0 parameters and warn 960 invalid_ar = ( 961 self.k_ar > 0 and 962 self.enforce_stationarity and 963 not is_invertible(np.r_[1, -params_ar]) 964 ) File ~\.conda\envs\sktime_arima\lib\site-packages\statsmodels\tsa\statespace\sarimax.py:843, in SARIMAX._conditional_sum_squares(endog, k_ar, polynomial_ar, k_ma, polynomial_ma, k_trend, trend_data, warning_description) 839 residuals = Y - np.dot(X, params_ar) 841 # Run an ARMA(p,q) model using the just computed residuals as 842 # data --> 843 Y = endog[r:] 845 X = np.empty((Y.shape[0], 0)) 846 if k_trend > 0: IndexError: too many indices for array: array is 0-dimensional, but 1 were indexed

issue.title: [BUG] Fix default conformal intervals initial_window parameter

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
#### Reference Issues/PRs
Fixes #2889 

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.

Sets default `initial_window` to either 10 or 10% of the data (whichever is higher) and allows either an integer or a float to be passed

#### What should a reviewer concentrate their feedback on?

Is the choice of default the right one? I'm not sure we can have a foolproof default but this should solve most cases.


#### PR checklist
<!--
Please go through the checklist below. Please feel free to remove points if they are not applicable.
-->

##### For all contributions
- [ ] I've added myself to the [list of contributors](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/.all-contributorsrc).
- [ ] Optionally, I've updated sktime's [CODEOWNERS](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CODEOWNERS) to receive notifications about future changes to these files.
- [ ] I've added unit tests and made sure they pass locally.
- [ ] The PR title starts with either [ENH], [MNT], [DOC], or [BUG] indicating whether the PR topic is related to enhancement, maintenance, documentation, or bug.

##### For new estimators
- [ ] I've added the estimator to the online documentation.
- [ ] I've updated the existing example notebooks or provided a new one to showcase how my estimator works.


<!--
Thanks for contributing!
-->
